name: Emilia AOSE
comment info: I notice that this image shows how a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket creates a “triple boom” —three distinct sonic booms —as it falls back to Earth faster than the speed of sound. The red and blue cones represent waves of high and low pressure, which together produce the powerful “boom-buh-boom” sound pattern. This relates to my community because, as space travel and rocket launches become more common, people nearby will have to adapt to the noise, safety measures, and awe of modern space exploration. Catchy headline: “Echoes from the Edge: The Science Behind SpaceX’s Triple Sonic Boom”

name: Zachy G
comment info:
1. What do you notice?
    I notice that the graph shows bands of red and blue colors surrounding the Falcon 9 rocket as it travels back to Earth. The red bands represent areas of high pressure, and the blue bands represent low pressure. These pressure differences appear to come from the rocket’s movement through the atmosphere at speeds faster than sound. There are also labels like "Trailing Edge ... BOOM" and "Pressure Change ... BUH," which suggest specific points where sound waves (or sonic booms) are produced.
    2. What do you wonder?
    I wonder how often these sonic booms happen when rockets land and if there are ways to make them quieter. I’m also curious about how scientists can predict or reduce the impact of the pressure changes that cause these loud noises. Do certain weather conditions make the booms louder or quieter?
    3. How does this relate to you and your community?
    This relates to me and my community because as space travel becomes more common, rockets like Falcon 9 might land more often, even near where people live. Sonic booms could disturb neighborhoods, scare animals, or even cause damage to windows or buildings. Understanding how they work could help reduce the noise and protect people and their homes.
    4. Create a catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea.
    “BOOM! How SpaceX Rockets Shake the Skies—and What Scientists Are Doing About It”

This may sound crazy but maybe reducing engine and gas power and amplifying the electric power and motors can be a start in the right direction. Anything is possible nowadays including making a rocket quieter as it enters the atmosphere.

name: Alex
comment info: I notice that the colours look like colgate toothpaste. I wonder if the person making this graph uses Colgate or Crest. Did you know that the f22 has a gap between the fuselage and the air intakes? This is because low pressure air sticks to the body of the plane. If this low pressure air gets in the engine, it creates uneven tension on the turbofan, leading to accelerated engine wear. However, this gap increases the radar cross section of the plane. The f35, which was created 10+ years after the f22, uses a bulge instead of a gap to keep the radar cross section low.

name: Mac Comet
comment info: The graph shows a rocket (Falcon 9) from SpaceX as it is falling to the ground. There is a wide area of intense high pressure just below the engine of the rocket, and another, yet smaller pocket of intense high pressure below the fins. It quickly becomes much milder in just a few feet if you stray from the curve of intensity. There is a thin portion of low pressure between the mild high pressure at the legs and fins, and a larger area of low pressure behind the entire rocket. There is a sonic boom behind each low-pressure area and in front of each high-pressure area. The sonic boom occurs approximately 8 minutes after launch. I wonder what rocket has achieved the most sonic booms. There are no rockets launched in rural Michigan, but our county airport does have planes that take off, and they make a loud noise as they fly overhead. A catchy headline could be “The Booming Pressure of Rockets”

name: Jazmin Martin
comment info: The area of highest pressure occurs at the lower region of the cone-shaped shockwave produced by the rocket. Pressure is released from two primary points along this cone. Sonic booms can have noticeable effects on the surrounding environment. While they typically do not damage the rocket itself, the intense pressure waves can startle wildlife, rattle structures, and, in rare cases, cause minor damage near the ground. The reach of a sonic boom can extend for several miles, depending on the rocket’s altitude and speed. In nearby communities, the loud and sudden nature of sonic booms can be startling and potentially harmful, causing disturbances to both people and animals in the surrounding area Sonic Boom or Sonic Doom? The powerful sound may symbolize technological achievement, but it also raises questions about its environmental and social impact.

replies.comment info:
Hi @James M 672,
    I can tell that you put a lot of thought into the graph. Thank you for that. 
    
    The small graph shows that there is loud noise on takeoff and during the landing process. In that small graph, it just indicates that the landing process has 3 booms. It does not separate them in the small graph as it does in the larger graph.
    
    In the larger graph, you can see where it indicates the first boom is at the leading edge of the high pressure, the second noise, the “BUH” sound is at the pressure change, and the final boom is at the trailing edge of the low pressure. That is what they are referring to as the triple boom.
    
    You mention “a bunch of rocket boosters.” There are actually many different versions of the Falcon. The Falcon Heavy does have multiple boosters. The goal is for each of those multiple boosters to land safely so they can be reused. The illustration in this graph is of only one of those boosters. Do you think that with multiple boosters there are also multiple triple sonic booms? That would be a lot of booms! Keep noticing and wondering!
